### **Section 41 ‚Äì Insolvency's Impact**

**What it means:**
Where a party to an arbitration agreement becomes insolvent, the arbitration agreement becomes inoperative except with permission of the insolvency court/tribunal. Any pending arbitration abates. This aligns with insolvency law which centralizes all creditor claims before the insolvency authority.[^1_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
If the borrower enters insolvency proceedings (under Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code), you cannot proceed with arbitration without permission of the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) / Debt Recovery Tribunal (DRT). Your claim becomes part of the insolvency proceedings. The arbitration agreement is effectively suspended during insolvency.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
If you're undergoing insolvency resolution, the lender cannot arbitrarily continue arbitration against you. All claims must be submitted to the insolvency resolution professional. This provides you a breathing space from multiple legal proceedings and consolidates all debts in one forum.

**Practical Scenario:**
GlobalCredit initiates arbitration against borrower company TechStart Pvt Ltd for ‚Çπ1 crore loan default. After hearings begin, TechStart's board admits insolvency and Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process (CIRP) is initiated under IBC, 2016. An Interim Resolution Professional (IRP) is appointed. Under Section 41 of Arbitration Act read with Section 14 of IBC (moratorium), the arbitration proceedings are automatically stayed. GlobalCredit must now submit its claim to the IRP along with other creditors. The arbitration cannot proceed unless NCLT specifically permits it (which is rare).[^1_49]

***

### **Section 42 ‚Äì Which Court Has Power?**

**What it means:**
The court having jurisdiction over the arbitration is the one that would have jurisdiction over the subject matter of the arbitration if it were a civil suit. For appointments, interim relief, setting aside awards, etc., only this designated court has jurisdiction. Parties can file application at the place where arbitration is seated, where respondent/applicant resides, or where cause of action arose, subject to arbitration agreement.[^1_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
The "seat" of arbitration mentioned in your loan agreement's arbitration clause is critical ‚Äì that location's courts have jurisdiction for Section 9, 11, 34 applications. If your office is in Mumbai but you specified arbitration seat as Delhi, Delhi courts have exclusive jurisdiction for arbitration-related matters.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
Check the arbitration clause for "seat" or "place" of arbitration. That determines which courts you need to approach for any arbitration-related relief. If the seat is in a distant city, this increases your costs and difficulty in accessing justice. Try negotiating a local seat or institutional arbitration with virtual proceedings.

**Practical Scenario:**
ModernLoans (office: Bangalore) lends to borrower Harsh (resident: Jaipur). Loan agreement states: "Arbitration seat: Mumbai." Dispute arises. Harsh wants to file Section 34 application challenging the arbitral award. Under Section 42, he must file in the court within whose jurisdiction Mumbai falls (likely Bombay High Court or designated District Court in Mumbai), not in Jaipur courts or Bangalore courts. This requires Harsh to either travel to Mumbai multiple times or engage Mumbai

### **Section 43 ‚Äì Time Limits for Arbitration**

**What it means:**
The Limitation Act, 1963 applies to arbitrations as it applies to court proceedings. The limitation period for filing arbitration (or court suit) depends on the nature of claim ‚Äì for money claims on contracts, it's generally 3 years from when the cause of action arises. For invoking arbitration when already proceedings are ongoing, time limits specified elsewhere in the Act apply.[^1_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
If the borrower defaults, you have 3 years from the date of default (or last EMI payment) to commence arbitration. If you delay beyond 3 years, your claim becomes time-barred. However, each missed EMI payment may be a fresh cause of action. Send legal notices and commence arbitration within limitation to preserve your claim.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
If you want to invoke arbitration to challenge some aspect of the loan, you have 3 years from when your cause of action arose (like from when you discovered illegal charges were deducted). If the lender delays commencing arbitration beyond limitation, you can plead limitation as a defense ‚Äì the tribunal may reject their claim as time-barred.

**Practical Scenario:**
PayLater Finance lent ‚Çπ20 lakhs to borrower Amit in January 2018. Amit defaulted on the EMI due in February 2019. PayLater sent demand notices but took no legal action. In August 2023 (over 4 years later), PayLater initiates arbitration. Amit pleads Section 43 (applying Article 113 of Limitation Act ‚Äì 3 years for money claims). The tribunal finds that the cause of action arose in February 2019 (date of default), so limitation expired in February 2022. Arbitration initiated in August 2023 is barred by limitation. However, if Amit made any part payment or acknowledged the debt in between, limitation would restart from that date.[^1_35]

## **PART IA ‚Äì ARBITRATION COUNCIL OF INDIA**

*Note: Part IA (Sections 43A to 43M) provides for establishment of the Arbitration Council of India to grade arbitral institutions and accredit arbitrators. These sections are administrative in nature and have limited direct impact on individual loan disputes between lenders and borrowers. They establish a regulatory framework for professionalizing arbitration in India. For brevity and relevance to money-lending disputes, detailed individual explanation of Sections 43A-43M is omitted, as they govern the Council's structure, functions, grading criteria, and procedures rather than substantive rights of parties in disputes.*

## **PART II ‚Äì ENFORCEMENT OF CERTAIN FOREIGN AWARDS**

### **CHAPTER I ‚Äì NEW YORK CONVENTION AWARDS**

### **Section 44 ‚Äì What is a Foreign Award?**

**What it means:**
A "foreign award" under this chapter means an arbitral award made in a country that is signatory to the New York Convention (1958), and India must have declared that country as a reciprocating territory. The award must arise from international commercial disputes.[^1_23][^1_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
If you're a foreign lender or have international operations, and your borrower is in India, an award made in a foreign country (like Singapore, UK, USA ‚Äì New York Convention signatories) can be enforced in India under this chapter. Specify a New York Convention country as the seat of arbitration in cross-border loan agreements.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
If you took a loan from a foreign lender with arbitration seat outside India (in a New York Convention country), the foreign arbitral award can be enforced against you in India. You have limited defenses under Section 48. International arbitration is generally more expensive for you.

**Practical Scenario:**
US-based FinGlobal lends \$500,000 to Indian company ExportCo, with arbitration clause specifying seat as Singapore (New York Convention signatory). ExportCo defaults. Arbitration held in Singapore results in award favoring FinGlobal for \$600,000. FinGlobal can enforce this foreign award in Indian courts under Section 44-52. ExportCo cannot refuse enforcement simply by saying "this is a foreign award" ‚Äì India recognizes and enforces New York Convention awards.[^1_50][^1_23]

***

### **Section 45 ‚Äì Foreign Arbitration Agreement Must Be Respected**

**What it means:**
If a court case is filed in India on a matter subject to a foreign arbitration agreement (covered by New York Convention), the court must refer parties to arbitration unless it finds the arbitration agreement is null, inoperative, or incapable of being performed.[^1_23][^1_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
If your loan agreement with an Indian borrower specifies foreign arbitration (in a New York Convention country), and the borrower files suit in Indian court, you can invoke Section 45 to get the matter referred to arbitration. This parallels Section 8 but for foreign arbitration agreements.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
You cannot bypass a valid foreign arbitration clause by filing suit in Indian courts. If the lender invokes Section 45, the Indian court will refer the matter to arbitration in the foreign jurisdiction specified in the agreement (unless you prove the arbitration agreement

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
You cannot bypass a valid foreign arbitration clause by filing suit in Indian courts. If the lender invokes Section 45, the Indian court will refer the matter to arbitration in the foreign jurisdiction specified in the agreement (unless you prove the arbitration agreement is invalid).

London-based BritLoan lends ¬£200,000 to Indian businessman Vikram, with arbitration clause: "Disputes arbitrated in London under ICC Rules." Delhi High Court examines the arbitration clause, finds it valid and governed by New York Convention, and refers parties to arbitration in London. Vikram's Indian suit is dismissed with liberty to proceed to arbitration.[^1_36]

### **Sections 46-52 ‚Äì Enforcement of Foreign Awards**

**What they mean:**
These sections provide the procedure for enforcing foreign arbitral awards in India. Section 46: Foreign awards are binding and recognized in India. Section 47: Party seeking enforcement must produce original award (or certified copy), proof of finality, and evidence. Section 48: Grounds for refusing enforcement (similar to Section 34) ‚Äì invalid agreement, improper notice, beyond scope, improper procedure, not final, or contrary to public policy. Section 49: Enforced awards are treated as court decrees. Sections 50-52: Appeals and savings.[^1_51][^1_23][^1_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company (Foreign Lender):**
Winning a foreign arbitral award is only half the battle ‚Äì you must enforce it in India where the borrower's assets are located. File enforcement application in the appropriate Indian court (usually High Court) with the award and supporting documents. The borrower can resist enforcement only on limited grounds under Section 48. Once enforced, the award becomes a decree and you can execute it against the borrower's Indian assets.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
If a foreign lender obtains an arbitral award against you abroad and seeks to enforce it in India, you can resist enforcement under Section 48 ‚Äì but grounds are very limited (similar to Section 34). You cannot re-argue the merits. If enforcement is granted, the foreign award becomes an Indian court decree and the lender can attach your properties, bank accounts, etc.

**Practical Scenario:**
Dubai-based SheikhFinance obtains arbitral award from Dubai International Arbitration Centre (DIAC) against Indian borrower Sanjiv for AED 2 million (approx. ‚Çπ4.5 crores). SheikhFinance files enforcement application in Delhi High Court under Sections 47-49, producing the award, proof of finality, and evidence. Sanjiv opposes enforcement citing Section 48, claiming he was not given proper notice of arbitration. High Court examines evidence, finds Sanjiv was served notice at his email address (as per agreement) and participated in initial stages before withdrawing. Court finds no Section 48 grounds satisfied. The foreign award is enforced ‚Äì treated as Delhi High Court decree. SheikhFinance proceeds to execute against Sanjiv's properties in India.[^1_51]

### **CHAPTER II ‚Äì GENEVA CONVENTION AWARDS**

### **Sections 53-60 ‚Äì Older Foreign Award Regime**

**What they mean:**
These sections govern enforcement of foreign arbitral awards under the older Geneva Convention (1927). The principles are similar to New York Convention but apply to fewer countries. Section 53 defines foreign awards under Geneva Convention. Sections 54-60 provide mechanism for referring parties to arbitration and enforcing such awards in India.[^1_26][^1_23][^1_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
Geneva Convention is now less relevant as most countries have acceded to the newer New York Convention. However, if dealing with a country that's only party to Geneva Convention (not New York), these sections apply. Practically, for modern international lending, focus on New York Convention.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
If you're dealing with a very old foreign arbitral award or a lender from a Geneva-Convention-only country, these sections govern enforcement. The principles are similar to New York Convention but with slightly different procedures.

**Practical Scenario:**
Swiss lender AlpineBank obtained an arbitral award in 1998 under Geneva Convention against Indian company OldTrade Ltd (before India acceded to New York Convention for Switzerland). AlpineBank now seeks to enforce this old award. Sections 53-60 provide the framework. However, this is rare in modern practice ‚Äì most foreign award enforcement now happens under New York Convention (Sections 44-52).[^1_23][^1_26]

## **PART III ‚Äì CONCILIATION**

*Note: Conciliation is an alternative dispute resolution method where a neutral conciliator helps parties reach a voluntary settlement. Unlike arbitration, the conciliator doesn't impose a decision ‚Äì parties must agree. Conciliation is relevant for money-lending disputes as a pre-arbitration or alternative mechanism to preserve relationships while resolving disputes.*

### **Section 61 ‚Äì When Does Conciliation Apply?**

### **Section 61 ‚Äì When Does Conciliation Apply?**

**What it means:**
Part III applies to conciliation of disputes arising from legal relationships (contractual or otherwise), unless parties agreed otherwise or some law prohibits conciliation of certain disputes.[^1_48][^1_49][^1_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
You can include a conciliation clause in loan agreements: "Disputes shall first be attempted to be resolved through conciliation, failing which arbitration." This two-tier mechanism often results in negotiated settlements, saving time and costs. Conciliation is particularly useful for borrowers facing genuine hardship (pandemic, business loss) where negotiated restructuring benefits both parties.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
If your loan agreement has a conciliation clause, or if the lender proposes conciliation, participate actively. Conciliation is non-binding until settlement is reached ‚Äì you can walk away if terms aren't acceptable. It's less adversarial than arbitration and gives you chance to explain your circumstances and negotiate manageable repayment terms.

**Practical Scenario:**
RuralMicroFin lends to 1000 small borrowers with clause: "Disputes shall first attempt conciliation." During pandemic, 300 borrowers default. Instead of filing 300 arbitrations, RuralMicroFin initiates conciliation proceedings. A neutral conciliator meets with borrower groups, understands hardships, and facilitates settlement: extended repayment period, partial interest waiver. 250 borrowers agree to settlement (recorded under Section 73), resolving disputes quickly. Remaining 50 proceed to arbitration. Conciliation saved enormous time and costs for both sides.[^1_52][^1_49]

***

### **Section 62 ‚Äì How Does Conciliation Start?**

**What it means:**
One party sends written invitation to the other party to conciliate, briefly identifying the dispute. Conciliation commences when the other party accepts the invitation in writing. If invitation is rejected, there's no conciliation.[^1_48][^1_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
To initiate conciliation, send formal invitation to borrower identifying the dispute (EMI defaults, outstanding amount, etc.). If borrower accepts, conciliation commences. If borrower rejects or doesn't respond within reasonable time, you can proceed directly to arbitration.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
If you receive conciliation invitation, consider accepting ‚Äì it gives you opportunity to negotiate without adversarial proceedings. Accepting doesn't mean conceding liability; it just means you're willing to discuss settlement. If conciliation fails, you can still defend in arbitration later.

**Practical Scenario:**
UrbanFinance sends conciliation invitation to borrower Anita: "We invite conciliation to resolve outstanding amount of ‚Çπ8 lakhs on your loan. Please confirm acceptance within 15 days." Anita responds: "I accept invitation for conciliation. However, I dispute ‚Çπ2 lakhs as illegal charges." Under Section 62, conciliation proceedings have commenced. Both parties now work with a conciliator to resolve the dispute. The fact that Anita disputes part of the claim doesn't prevent conciliation ‚Äì that's what conciliation is meant to resolve.[^1_53][^1_48]

***

### **Section 63 ‚Äì How Many Conciliators?**

**What it means:**
There shall be one conciliator unless parties agree on two or three. Multiple conciliators should generally act jointly.[^1_48][^1_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
For most loan disputes, a sole conciliator is sufficient and cost-effective. For large or complex disputes, parties might agree on three conciliators for broader perspectives.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
Unless you have specific reasons to insist on multiple conciliators (like wanting diverse perspectives), agree to a sole conciliator to keep process simple and costs low.

**Practical Scenario:**
BankCorp and borrower company TechManufacturing have a ‚Çπ5 crore loan dispute. Given the complexity, they agree on three conciliators under Section 63: one with finance expertise, one with legal expertise, and one with industry expertise. The three conciliators work jointly, bringing multidisciplinary perspective to facilitate settlement discussions.[^1_54][^1_48]

***

### **Section 64 ‚Äì Appointing the Peacemaker**

**What it means:**
For sole conciliator, parties may agree on a name. For two conciliators, each party appoints one. For three conciliators, each party appoints one and parties agree on the third. Parties may seek assistance from institutions for appointments.[^1_48][^1_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
Maintain a panel of qualified conciliators or tie-up with conciliation institutions (like MCCIA, IIAM) for neutral appointments. Avoid unilateral appointment clauses which create perception of bias.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
Participate in conciliator selection. Ensure the conciliator is truly neutral ‚Äì someone with experience in financial disputes, known for fairness, not someone closely associated with lender.

**Practical Scenario:**
ConsumerLoan and borrower Prakash agree to conciliation. Under Section 64(1)(a), they jointly select retired banker Mr. Sharma as sole conciliator, respecting his experience and impartiality. Had they disagreed, they could have approached an institution like the Indian Institute of Arbitration \& Mediation (IIAM) to suggest a neutral conciliator.[^1_55][^1_48]

## **PART III ‚Äì CONCILIATION (Continued)**

### **Section 66 ‚Äì The Conciliator is Not Bound by Court Rules**

**Section Number:** 66

**Simple Title:** Conciliator Not Bound by Civil Procedure Code or Evidence Act

**What it means:**
The conciliator is not bound by the Civil Procedure Code, 1908 (CPC) or the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 (IEA). The conciliator decides the procedure themselves and can accept evidence that wouldn't normally be admissible in court.[^2_1][^2_2][^2_3]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
This flexibility allows you to present business records, internal memos, email communications, and other informal evidence without strict procedural formalities. You don't need to follow court rules for document authentication or witness examination. This speeds up the conciliation process.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
You can present your side informally without worrying about technical legal procedures. You can submit family WhatsApp messages showing you discussed hardship with the lender, personal health records explaining inability to pay, or business documents showing losses ‚Äì evidence that might not be admissible in court can be considered by the conciliator.

**Practical Scenario:**
During conciliation between UrbanCredit and borrower Rahul over ‚Çπ18 lakh outstanding, under Section 66, the conciliator accepts: (i) Rahul's unattested photocopy of salary slips showing reduced salary; (ii) screenshots of WhatsApp conversation between Rahul and UrbanCredit's manager (discussing hardship); (iii) Rahul's personal health records (in Marathi) showing medical expenses that depleted savings. In court, these might face authentication issues. But under Section 66, the conciliator considers all these to understand Rahul's circumstances and facilitate settlement. This informal approach helps conciliator grasp ground realities.[^2_2][^2_4]

***

### **Section 67 ‚Äì The Conciliator's Role and Duty (The Neutral Bridge)**

**Section Number:** 67

**Simple Title:** Role of Conciliator ‚Äì Neutrality, Fairness, and Settlement Focus

**What it means:**
The conciliator's role is to assist parties in reaching an amicable settlement amicably and expeditiously. The conciliator must be independent and impartial, act fairly and in good faith, and consider: (a) the rights and obligations of parties, (b) usages and practices in trade/commerce, (c) circumstances of the dispute including prior dealings between parties. The conciliator has absolute discretion in procedure and can propose settlement terms at any stage.[^2_3][^2_1][^2_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
The conciliator will consider your legitimate business interests (recovering debt, avoiding precedent of waiving principal) but also expects fairness. If the borrower genuinely faces hardship and can afford restructured payment, the conciliator will push for a realistic settlement. Participate genuinely; don't come to conciliation just for show.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
The conciliator is truly neutral ‚Äì not on either side. They'll push both lender and borrower to move towards middle ground. Be transparent about your circumstances. The conciliator can propose creative solutions (like extending repayment period, reducing interest, or converting part of debt to smaller monthly installments). Listen to the conciliator's suggestions ‚Äì they're aimed at fair settlement benefiting both sides.

**Practical Scenario:**
In conciliation between BusinessFinance and borrower Priya over ‚Çπ25 lakh business loan, Priya claims total hardship; BusinessFinance says Priya is misusing funds. Under Section 67, the conciliator: (i) meets both separately to understand their positions, (ii) reviews the loan agreement and Priya's business records, (iii) considers trade practice (in Priya's industry, how many businesses survive pandemic downturn?), (iv) notes prior dealings (was Priya's initial repayment record good?), and (v) proposes: "Priya pays ‚Çπ20 lakhs over 36 months instead of 24 months; remaining ‚Çπ5 lakhs converted to zero-interest loan payable after 3 years when business recovers; BusinessFinance waives penalties." This balanced proposal under Section 67 becomes acceptable to both sides.[^2_5][^2_2]

***

### **Section 68 ‚Äì Getting Administrative Help in Conciliation**

**Section Number:** 68

**Simple Title:** Administrative Assistance for Conciliation Proceedings

**What it means:**
The parties or conciliator can arrange for administrative assistance from suitable institutions or persons (similar to Section 6 for arbitration). This helps with scheduling, document management, venue, etc..[^2_2][^2_3]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
Engage a professional conciliation institution (like IIAM ‚Äì Indian Institute of Arbitration \& Mediation, or JAMS ‚Äì Judicial Arbitration and Mediation Services) to manage the administrative aspects. This brings professionalism, maintains confidentiality, and ensures neutral environment.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
Institutional support ensures the conciliation isn't just in a lender's office where you might feel uncomfortable speaking freely. A neutral institution with trained administrative staff creates balanced environment.

**Practical Scenario:**
SamllBiz NBFC and borrower Arun agree to conciliation. Instead of meeting at NBFC's office, they engage IIAM (Indian Institute of Arbitration \& Mediation) under Section 68 to provide administrative support. IIAM: (i) provides neutral venue (their office), (ii) arranges video conferencing for parties in different cities, (iii) maintains confidential file, (iv) schedules meetings, (v) manages document exchange, (vi) arranges interpreter if needed. This institutional support

### **Section 69 ‚Äì How the Conciliator Communicates (Flexible Communication Methods)**

**Section Number:** 69

**Simple Title:** Communication Between Conciliator and Parties ‚Äì Joint and Separate Meetings

**What it means:**
The conciliator can communicate with parties through written or oral means, as the conciliator considers appropriate. The conciliator can meet parties jointly or separately (caucusing). The conciliator also determines when to communicate and which parties to communicate with. This flexibility in communication methods facilitates settlement.[^2_1][^2_3][^2_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
The conciliator might hold separate meetings with you (caucuses) to discuss your actual bottom line without the borrower present. In a joint meeting, you might take a hardline; in a separate meeting, you might admit you can accept restructuring. Use separate meetings strategically to signal flexibility.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
Separate meetings (caucuses) are your opportunity to speak frankly with the conciliator ‚Äì explain genuine hardship, your maximum payment capacity, emotional stress. You don't need to maintain a "tough defense" in front of the lender. The conciliator can then explore with the lender whether your offer is acceptable. Some borrowers find caucuses more comfortable than confrontational joint meetings.

**Practical Scenario:**
In conciliation between LoanMax and borrower Sanjay, the conciliator under Section 69: (i) holds a joint meeting where LoanMax claims ‚Çπ20 lakhs outstanding and Sanjay insists he can pay only ‚Çπ5 lakhs (wide gap); (ii) meets LoanMax separately ‚Äì they admit they can accept ‚Çπ18 lakhs if structured over 48 months with 3% interest; (iii) meets Sanjay separately ‚Äì he admits he can actually afford ‚Çπ12 lakhs over 36 months but was afraid to offer more in front of aggressive lender. Conciliator now proposes middle ground via separate communications: LoanMax gets ‚Çπ15 lakhs over 40 months at 5% interest. Both find this acceptable through caucusing.[^2_7][^2_2]

### **Section 70 ‚Äì What Can the Conciliator Disclose? (Confidentiality with Exceptions)**

**Section Number:** 70

**Simple Title:** Disclosure of Information by Conciliator ‚Äì When Information Can Be Shared

**What it means:**
Information given by one party to the conciliator may be disclosed to the other party, except where a party objects. However, the conciliator can disclose any information agreed to be disclosed by both parties or information already in the public domain or essential for implementing settlement.[^2_3][^2_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
If you tell the conciliator (in separate meeting) your actual bottom line and conciliator asks "Can I share this with the borrower?", you can object ‚Äì then the conciliator won't disclose your exact limits. However, conciliator might paraphrase: "Lender might be open to ‚Çπ18 lakhs" without revealing your exact figures.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
If in a separate meeting you share sensitive information (like "My business is bankrupt, I have no other funds"), you can request the conciliator keep it confidential. However, general information like "I can pay ‚Çπ10 lakhs" the conciliator may share with lender (unless you specifically object). Be strategic about what you mark as confidential.

**Practical Scenario:**
During caucus between conciliator and borrower Meera under Section 70, Meera reveals: "I took ‚Çπ3 lakhs from my parents to make partial payment to the lender. I cannot ask them for more. My maximum capacity is ‚Çπ2 lakhs additional payment." Meera requests: "Please don't tell the lender that I borrowed from my parents ‚Äì they'll think I'm just hiding money." Conciliator agrees to keep that confidential. But conciliator tells the lender: "Borrower has limited additional funds, can realistically pay ‚Çπ2 lakhs more, total ‚Çπ5 lakhs." The specific source (parents' loan) remains confidential under Section 70, but relevant payment capacity is disclosed.[^2_8][^2_2]

### **Section 74 ‚Äì Settlement Agreement is a Decree (Enforcement Power)**

**Section Number:** 74

**Simple Title:** Status and Effect of Settlement Agreement ‚Äì Execution as Court Decree

**What it means:**
The settlement agreement made under Section 73 shall be treated as an arbitral award on agreed terms under Section 30 of this Act. It has the same status, effect, and enforceability as a court decree or arbitral award. It can be executed directly without filing a fresh suit.[^2_2][^2_3]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
If the borrower defaults on the restructured payment plan (e.g., misses EMI under settlement), you don't file a fresh suit. You directly approach the executing court with the authenticated settlement agreement and file execution application. The court will treat it as a decree and attach borrower's property, bank accounts, salary, etc. This makes settlement agreements highly valuable ‚Äì they're immediately enforceable.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
The settlement agreement is a double-edged sword. While it protects you (lender cannot demand more than what's in settlement), it's also immediately enforceable against you. If you default even by one day on the restructured payment schedule in the settlement, the lender can execute it against your property. Ensure you commit only to what you can realistically afford.

**Practical Scenario:**
Through Section 73, SmartsLoan and borrower Rahul sign settlement: "Rahul pays ‚Çπ1 lakh on 1st January 2025, then ‚Çπ40,000 on 1st of each month for 24 months; SmartsLoan waives all penalties and reduces interest." The conciliator authenticates this under Section 73(4). This authenticated settlement becomes enforceable under Section 74 as a decree. Rahul pays January to June (6 months) on time. On 1st July, he defaults (‚Çπ40,000 not paid). Under Section 74, SmartsLoan directly approaches the District Court with the settlement agreement (no new suit filed) and files execution application seeking attachment of Rahul's property and bank account. The court treats the settlement like a court judgment and proceeds with execution. Unlike if Rahul had simply borrowed ‚Çπ15 lakhs and defaulted (requiring a new lawsuit), here the settlement agreement itself is the decree.[^2_12][^2_2]

### **Section 76 ‚Äì When Does Conciliation End? (Termination Scenarios)**

**Section Number:** 76

**Simple Title:** Termination of Conciliation Proceedings ‚Äì Four Ways to End

**What it means:**
Conciliation proceedings terminate in the following cases:

(a) By signing of the settlement agreement by the parties (on date of agreement);

(b) By written declaration of the conciliator (after consulting parties) that further efforts at conciliation are no longer justified (on date of declaration);

(c) By written declaration of the parties addressed to the conciliator that conciliation is terminated (on date of declaration);

(d) By written declaration of the conciliator upon default in deposit of costs (if parties don't pay deposits within 30 days) ‚Äì conciliator may suspend or terminate.[^2_2][^2_3]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
If you feel conciliation isn't progressing and you want to move to arbitration, you can jointly request (with borrower) termination under 76(c), or if you and borrower cannot agree, wait for the conciliator to declare further efforts unjustified under 76(b). You can also terminate by defaulting on cost deposits (under 76(d)), though this is aggressive and risks being seen as bad faith.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
If conciliation becomes frustrating (lender is unreasonable or your financial position is truly irreconcilable with lender's demands), you can jointly request termination under 76(c) or wait for conciliator to declare it hopeless under 76(b). If you cannot afford the cost deposits, failure to pay under 76(d) terminates conciliation. However, this may be seen as bad faith termination.

**Practical Scenario:**
Case 1 ‚Äì Successful Settlement [76(a)]: MicroBank and borrower Geeta successfully settle on terms "‚Çπ8 lakhs over 30 months." They sign settlement agreement on 15th March. Conciliation terminates on 15th March under 76(a).

Case 2 ‚Äì Impasse [76(b)]: CapitalCorp and borrower Vikram have been in conciliation for 3 months. CapitalCorp demands ‚Çπ18 lakhs total; Vikram can pay maximum ‚Çπ10 lakhs. The gap is unbridgeable. After 5 meetings with no progress, the conciliator declares under 76(b) on 30th June: "Further efforts at conciliation are no longer justified." Conciliation terminates. Both parties can now proceed to arbitration.

Case 3 ‚Äì Joint Termination [76(c)]: PrimeFinance and borrower Anil realize conciliation isn't helping and both want to proceed to arbitration (their agreement allows either party to choose). On 10th May, both jointly request termination. Conciliation terminates on 10th May under 76(c).

Case 4 ‚Äì Cost Default [76(d)]: ConsumerLoan requires parties to deposit ‚Çπ1 lakh each for conciliator's costs. Borrower Rishi fails to deposit within 30 days. Conciliator warns, then declares termination on 25th July under 76(d) for cost default.[^2_9][^2_2]

Similarly, don't initiate parallel court cases while conciliation is ongoing ‚Äì this dilutes focus and suggests lack of faith in conciliation. However, if the lender is harassing you (threatening illegal repossession), you can urgently approach court for protection. ### **Section 78 ‚Äì Who Pays the Conciliator? (Cost Allocation)**

**Section Number:** 78

**Simple Title:** Costs of Conciliation ‚Äì Conciliator Fees and Expenses

**What it means:**
Section 78(1): The conciliator fixes the fees and expenses (conciliator's compensation, administrative costs, witness expenses if with parties' consent, expert advice with consent, assistance provided under Sections 64 and 68).

Section 78(2): Unless the settlement agreement provides otherwise, costs are borne by the parties in equal parts.[^2_3][^2_2]

Conciliation costs are typically split equally ‚Äì each party pays 50% of conciliator's fees and administrative expenses. However, in the settlement agreement, you can negotiate cost allocation. You'll pay 50% of conciliation costs (conciliator's fees typically ‚Çπ5,000-‚Çπ50,000 depending on dispute amount, plus institutional fees if any). However, this is often much cheaper than arbitration (arbitrators charge 1-2% of claim amount) or litigation. If you settle through conciliation, the lower costs make it worthwhile. mediation before Section 34 hearing in some cases, (iii) filing affidavit with specific details. Ensure your lawyer knows the local High Court's rules.

**Practical Scenario:**
Arbitration Award decided in favor of LendRight against borrower Neha for ‚Çπ18 lakhs. Neha wants to challenge under Section 34. She hires lawyer in Delhi. Delhi High Court has framed "Delhi High Court Arbitration Rules, 2018" under Section 82. These rules require: (i) Section 34 application in specific format, (ii) detailed affidavit explaining grounds, (iii) certified copy of entire arbitration record, (iv) supporting documents. Neha's lawyer follows these rules precisely. If a lawyer in Delhi files Section 34 application ignoring these court-specific rules (e.g., missing grounds of challenge in affidavit), the application can be rejected for non-compliance with Section 82 rules.[^2_14][^2_2]

### **Section 83 ‚Äì Government Can Remove Implementation Difficulties (Administrative Flexibility)**

**Section Number:** 83

**Simple Title:** Central Government's Power to Remove Difficulties in Implementation

**What it means:**
If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Act, the Central Government may issue orders to remove such difficulty. However: (i) this power exists only for 2 years from the Act's commencement (now expired ‚Äì 1996 Act commencement was 1996, so this power expired in 1998), (ii) government orders cannot be inconsistent with the Act, (iii) all government orders must be published in the Official Gazette.[^2_14][^2_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
This section is now mostly historical (power expired in 1998). However, government can issue orders to clarify ambiguities. For instance, if there's confusion whether arbitration started under old law continues under new amendments, government can clarify via Section 83 order. Monitor government gazette notifications related to arbitration.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
Government orders under Section 83 (if any) provide authoritative interpretation of the Act and clarify grey areas. These orders have legal force and courts follow them. Keep updated on any government orders clarifying arbitration procedures.

**Practical Scenario:**
In 1998, when the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 faced implementation confusion (e.g., whether Section 29A's 12-month timeline applied to arbitrations started before this provision), the Government could have issued an order under Section 83(2) clarifying this. However, since the power expired by 1998, no such order was issued. Later, when the 2015 Amendment Act added Section 29A, the government didn't use Section 83 (power expired) but instead amended the Act directly via Section 87, clarifying applicability to future arbitrations.[^2_2]

***

### **Section 84 ‚Äì Government Can Make Detailed Rules (Regulatory Framework)**

**Section Number:** 84

**Simple Title:** Power of Central Government to Make Rules ‚Äì Detailed Procedures and Standards

**What it means:**
The Central Government may make rules to carry out the provisions of the Act, including rules regarding: (i) institutional arbitration, (ii) arbitrator accreditation and qualification, (iii) arbitration procedures, (iv) arbitration institutions' grading, (v) fee structures, etc. All rules must be laid before Parliament.[^2_14][^2_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
Government rules (framed under Section 84) determine: arbitrator qualifications (minimum education, experience), fee caps (Fourth Schedule rates), accreditation of arbitration institutions, disclosure requirements, standards for conducting proceedings. These rules standardize arbitration practice. When selecting an arbitrator or institution, ensure they comply with government rules.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
Government rules protect you by: requiring arbitrators to have certain qualifications, capping their fees, requiring institutional accreditation, ensuring transparency. If an arbitrator is not qualified per government rules or charges fees exceeding Fourth Schedule, you can challenge such fees.

**Practical Scenario:**
Under Section 84, the Ministry of Law and Justice framed "Arbitration and Conciliation (Amendment) Rules, 2022." These rules specify: (i) Arbitrators must have at least 10 years of legal/professional experience, (ii) Arbitrators on the high court's panel must have specialized training, (iii) Arbitration institutions must be government-graded A/B/C categories, (iv) Arbitrator fees for claims ‚Çπ20-50 lakhs shall not exceed ‚Çπ2.5 lakhs. When FinTech NBFC and borrower Vishal agree to arbitration, they ensure: selected arbitrator has 10+ years experience, selected institution is government-graded, and agreed fees comply with Fourth Schedule (per Section 84 rules).[^2_2]

***

### **Section 85 ‚Äì Old Arbitration Laws Repealed (Transitional Provision)**

**Section Number:** 85

**Simple Title:** Repeal of Pre-1996 Arbitration Laws ‚Äì Clean Slate

**What it means:**
Section 85(1): Three old laws are repealed: (a) Arbitration Act, 1940, (b) Arbitration (Protocol and Convention) Act, 1937, (c) Foreign Awards (Recognition and Enforcement) Act, 1961.

Section 85(2): Notwithstanding repeal, proceedings commenced under those old laws before the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 came into force (22nd August, 1996) shall continue under old laws.[^2_14][^2_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
This is transitional. If you have arbitrations still pending that started under the 1940 Act

chunk-16b68b020bbfd3da9f8de311e1a7db8a.content:
, (c) Foreign Awards (Recognition and Enforcement) Act, 1961.

Section 85(2): Notwithstanding repeal, proceedings commenced under those old laws before the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 came into force (22nd August, 1996) shall continue under old laws.[^2_14][^2_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
This is transitional. If you have arbitrations still pending that started under the 1940 Act (before 1996), they continue under 1940 Act rules. But practically, all arbitrations starting after 1996 are under the 1996 Act. Update your arbitration clauses to explicitly cite "Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996."

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
Old arbitrations (pre-1996) follow old law rules. New arbitrations (post-1996) follow 1996 Act. The 1996 Act provides better protections (more neutral arbitrator selection, clearer procedures, stronger public policy grounds for setting aside awards). If somehow an old arbitration is still pending, you're stuck with old law ‚Äì less protective.

**Practical Scenario:**
HeritageCorp's 1994 loan agreement with borrower MrOldBusiness contained arbitration clause referring to "Arbitration Act, 1940." Arbitration was initiated in 1995 but remained pending due to procedural delays. After August 22, 1996, the 1940 Act was repealed by Section 85. However, under Section 85(2), this pending 1995 arbitration continues under 1940 Act rules (not switched to 1996 Act rules). MrOldBusiness is stuck with older, less protective procedures. If the arbitration were started in 1997, it would be under 1996 Act with better protections.[^2_2]

***

### **Section 86 ‚Äì Saving for Old Foreign Awards (Ancient Awards Still Enforceable)**

**Section Number:** 86

**Simple Title:** Saving Provision for Pre-1996 Foreign Awards under Geneva Convention

**What it means:**
Section 86: Although the Foreign Awards (Recognition and Enforcement) Act, 1961 is repealed by Section 85, any foreign arbitral award made before August 22, 1996 (under the Geneva Convention, 1927) can still be enforced under the saved provisions of the 1961 Act.[^2_14][^2_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
Very old foreign awards (before 1996) under Geneva Convention can still be enforced using the old 1961 Act framework. However, practically, most pre-1996 foreign awards are now time-barred or unenforceable due to laches (delay). This section preserves their enforceability in principle.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
If there's an ancient foreign arbitral award against you (pre-1996, Geneva Convention-based), the creditor can still attempt enforcement under the saved 1961 Act provisions. However, you might have defenses: limitation period, change of circumstances, impossibility of performance, etc.

**Practical Scenario:**
In 1991, a French court made an arbitral award against Indian importer VintageGoods under Geneva Convention. The French creditor never enforced it. In 2024, the French creditor discovers VintageGoods is doing better financially and tries enforcement. Under Section 86, the 1961 Act's provisions are saved ‚Äì the creditor can attempt enforcement using old 1961 Act procedures (which are now quite dated). However, VintageGoods argues: (a) 33-year limitation period should apply, (b) award is time-barred, (c) VintageGoods' circumstances have changed. Courts might reject the enforcement on these grounds despite Section 86's saving.[^2_2]

***

### **Section 87 ‚Äì The Critical Transition Rule (When Do Amendments Apply?)**

**Section Number:** 87

**Simple Title:** Effect of 2015 and 2019 Amendments ‚Äì Applicability to Pending Arbitrations

**What it means:**
Section 87 (added by 2015 Amendment Act and further amended in 2019):

(1) The amendments made by the 2015 Amendment Act (which added Sections 29A, 29B, and strengthened arbitrator independence rules) apply to arbitral proceedings commenced on or after October 23, 2015.

(2) Court proceedings arising from such arbitrations also follow the amended Act.

(3) Arbitrations commenced before October 23, 2015 continue under the pre-2015 law (unless parties expressly agree to apply new provisions).

(4) The 2019 Amendment (further clarifying public policy) applies similarly.[^2_14][^2_2]

**Effect for Money-Lending Company:**
Check when the arbitration commenced. If before October 23, 2015: old law applies (no mandatory 12-month deadline under Section 29A, more lenient arbitrator rules, older cost regime). If on or after October 23, 2015: new law applies (12-month deadline with 6-month extension possible, stricter arbitrator independence, clearer fee structures). This significantly impacts your arbitration strategy ‚Äì timelines differ.

**Effect for Customer/Borrower:**
If arbitration started before October 23, 2015, old rules apply ‚Äì potentially more favorable to borrowers (less time pressure on arbitrator, less strict arbitrator independence rules, but also less protection). If on or after October 23, 2015, new rules apply ‚Äì stronger protections (strict arbitrator independence, mandatory timelines, reduced arbitrator fees for delays).

**Practical Scenario:**
FastLoan Finance initiated arbitration against borrower Ramesh on September 1, 2015 (before October 23,

23, 2015, old rules apply ‚Äì potentially more favorable to borrowers (less time pressure on arbitrator, less strict arbitrator independence rules, but also less protection). If on or after October 23, 2015, new rules apply ‚Äì stronger protections (strict arbitrator independence, mandatory timelines, reduced arbitrator fees for delays). **Practical Scenario:** FastLoan Finance initiated arbitration against borrower Ramesh on September 1, 2015 (before October 23, 2015 cutoff). The arbitration continues under pre-2015 law. Section 29A's 12-month deadline doesn't apply ‚Äì arbitration can drag on. On October 24, 2015, FastLoan initiates separate arbitration against borrower Neha. Neha's arbitration is governed by post-2015 law ‚Äì must conclude within 12 months (extendable to 18 months). This creates two different timelines for similar disputes. Later, the 2019 Amendment clarifies public policy grounds for setting aside awards. For Ramesh's pre-2015 arbitration, even after 2019, the old public policy definition applies. For Neha's post-2015 arbitration, the 2019-amended public policy applies. Section 87 ensures old arbitrations aren't disrupted by new amendments but also means they're not modernized.[^2_2] *** ## **CONCLUSION** The Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 provides a comprehensive framework for resolving disputes outside traditional courts. For money-lending companies and borrowers, key takeaways are: **For Lenders:** - Draft clear, neutral arbitration clauses (avoid unilateral arbitrator appointment) - Specify seat of arbitration and consider fast-track for smaller claims - Maintain proper documentation for efficient arbitration - Consider conciliation for relationship preservation - Act within limitation periods and comply with timelines **For Borrowers:** - Read and understand arbitration clauses before signing - Participate actively in arbitration ‚Äì don't ignore notices - Challenge biased arbitrators early (Section 12-13) - Preserve rights to challenge awards (Section 34 ‚Äì only 3 months!) - Consider conciliation for negotiated settlements Both parties benefit from arbitration's speed and privacy compared to court litigation, provided the process is fair, neutral, and conducted in good faith.[^1_60][^1_61][^1_3][^1_5][^1_4][^1_7][^1_8][^1_1][^1_2] *** *This guide is based on the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 as amended up to 2019, along with judicial interpretations and practical applications in financial disputes.* [^1_62][^1_63][^1_64][^1_65][^1_66][^1_67][^1_68][^1_69][^1_70][^1_71]
